Award.AbstractNarration: This project will support the Post Doctoral training and research of Dr. Drew Gerkey. Dr. Gerkey will be based at the University of Washington where he will undergo training in network analysis working closely with his sponsors Dr. Donna Leonetti and Dr. Eric Smith. Dr. Gerkey's Post Doctoral research will include field sites in Alaska and in Kamchatka, Russia where he will be working with salmon fishing communities to examine the how the formation of networks of interdependence and support contribute to our understanding of how cooperative interactions between individuals have cumulative effects at the community level. As part of the Post Doctoral Fellowship, Dr. Gerkey will be developing and teaching undergraduate courses and training arctic community members in new media technology so that they can document their lives themselves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the professional development and scholarly research of an early-career researcher in the fields of anthropology and Arctic social science, Dr. Drew Gerkey.  Dr. Gerkey’s research examines interactions between people and their environments, focusing on the role of cooperation in the traditional subsistence activities, social networks, post-Soviet institutions, and social movements of indigenous peoples living in the Kamchatka Peninsula in Northeast Siberia.  This project provided Dr. Gerkey with opportunities to acquire new skills in the quantitative analysis of social networks and apply these skills to investigate the role networks play in facilitating cooperation at various scales.  Specifically, Dr. Gerkey combines network analysis with qualitative ethnographic research to understand: (1) how households produce and circulate subsistence resources, (2) how institutions facilitate these activities by coordinating labor and providing access to resources, and (3) what role institutions play in environmental conservation, economic development, and indigenous rights.  This project also provided Dr. Gerkey with opportunities to collaborate with an inter-disciplinary team of anthropologists and economists examining how Arctic salmon fishing communities in Kamchatka and Alaska use formal and informal institutions to cope with environmental risk.  Together, these research activities improve our understanding of how institutions help people balance individual and common interests, building and sustaining successful institutions from the bottom-up. This knowledge can help us identify ways existing institutions can be improved and develop effective approaches for building new institutions, a crucial challenge facing communities throughout the world as they confront forces of ecological, economic, cultural, and political change.  This project also provided opportunities for Dr. Gerkey to make broader impacts through education and outreach.  Dr. Gerkey designed and taught an upper-level undergraduate seminar titled, “Arctic Perspectives on Global Problems.” This course featured research from the circumpolar Arctic to examine pressing issues such as climate change, energy extraction, natural resource management, and traditional ecological knowledge.  Dr. Gerkey also worked with community leaders in Kamchatka to develop a plan for an outreach project that would provide youth with training in the use of new media technologies to document their community’s traditions and contemporary ways of life.
